ol.label: a
ol.li: No, the length of c is shorter than the lengths of a and b combined, so c \lt a+b.

solution.p: No. In the previous example, c=\sqrt{a^2+b^2}, and we saw that c \lt a+b. We cannot simplify \sqrt{a^2+b^2} by taking the square root of each term.

statement.p:
If r=\sqrt{14}, write and simplify expressions for:
r \cdot r
r+r

ol.label: a
ol.li: r \cdot r = \left(\sqrt{14}\right)\left(\sqrt{14}\right) = 14. Or, r \cdot r = r^2 = \left(\sqrt{14}\right)^2 = 14.

introduction.p: To find the center and radius of a circle, we may need to complete the square.

statement.p: Write an equivalent equation in which the left side is a perfect square: ~x^2-6x=2

solution.p: We want to find a constant p^2 so that x^2\blert{-6x}+p^2 is a perfect square, namely (x+p)^2. Now, ~(x+p)^2 = x^2\blert{+2px}+p^2~, so 2p=-6, and p=-3. Thus, we add p^2=\alert{9} to both sides of the equation. x^2-6x+\alert{9} = 2+\alert{9} Now we can write the left side as a perfect square: (x-3)^2 = 11

subsection.title: 3. Use the equation for a circle

introduction.p: The equation for a circle of radius r centered at (h,k) is \blert{(x-h)^2+(y-k)^2=r^2}

solution.p: We substitute x=\alert{-1},~ y=\alert{5} into the equation for the circle. (\alert{-1}-1)^2+(\alert{5}-3)^2 = (-2)^2+2^2 = 4+4 = 8 The point (-1,5) satisfies the equation, so it does lie on the circle.
